definition: the mind/capacity for clear thinking
heart/mind/intention/center/core/CL:顆|颗[ke1],個|个[ge4]
hole/opening/orifice (of the human body)/(fig.) key (to the solution of a problem)
to be obsessed/to be possessed
mad about money (idiom)

sentences.english: It is very often nothing but our own vanity that deceives us.
sentences.chinese: 我們往往會因爲我們自己的虛榮心，而給弄迷了心竅。

sentences.english: We all need to use money but we need to be careful that we don't become tainted by it.
sentences.chinese: 我們都需要錢，但要小心不要因此而財迷心竅。

sentences.english: She had never been so crushed.
sentences.chinese: 她從來沒有這麼鬼迷心竅過。

sentences.english: Then he opened their minds so they could understand the Scriptures.
sentences.chinese: 於是耶穌開他們的心竅，使他們能明白聖經。

sentences.english: Nowadays, many girls seem to have a bee in their bonnets and they are determined to marry foreigners.
sentences.chinese: 最近許多女孩都鬼迷心竅似的一心只想嫁個外國人。

sentences.english: Then opened he their understanding, that they might understand the scriptures
sentences.chinese: 於是耶穌開他們的心竅，使他們能明白聖經。

sentences.english: She must have been possessed, to attack her own mother.
sentences.chinese: 她準是鬼迷心竅，竟然打自己的媽媽。

sentences.english: E. g. : Lisa is really monday hungry, who cares nothing but her wages.
sentences.chinese: 莉薩真是財迷心竅，一心只關心她工資。

sentences.english: There was a rumor saying the king was possessed by devils.
sentences.chinese: 有傳聞說國王被魔鬼迷住了心竅。

sentences.english: 45Then he opened their minds so they could understand the Scriptures.
sentences.chinese: 於是耶穌開他們的心竅，使他們能明白聖經。

sentences.english: Everything in our sight turns into the gold ingots.
sentences.chinese: 眼裏看到的，什麼都象元寶，真是個財迷心竅的民族。

sentences.english: You must either be mad or utterly depraved and wicked.
sentences.chinese: 你一定是瘋了，要不就是中了邪，鬼迷心竅。

definition: orpiment/arsenic trisulfide As2S3/make changes in writing/malign/criticize without grounds
to make an irrelevant comparison or interpretation (idiom)
Liuying township in Tainan county 台南縣|台南县[Tai2 nan2 xian4], Taiwan
to have a clear view of things/to adapt to circumstances
source of calamity (esp. of women)
to spin a cocoon around oneself (idiom); enmeshed in a trap of one's own devising/hoist by his own petard
root of Chinese pulsatilla/Chinese bulbul
to hate and resent/angry and full of grievances
to feel the pulse (TCM)/Taiwan pr. [zhen3 mo4]
shameful performance/disgraceful situation
to drink hard
to feel hatred/to harbor a grudge
many men, a great force (idiom); many hands provide great strength/There is safety in numbers.
to die (idiom)/to breathe one's last/to give up the ghost
muddle-headed
to amuse oneself/to play with/to tease
